intro: Fagonia kahirina, commonly known as the desert henna, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of North Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the family Capparaceae and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and pinnate leaves. The plant is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments through its deep root system and succulent leaves. It produces small, hard seeds that are dispersed by wind, aiding in its propagation across sandy soils. Fagonia kahirina is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
